docs.snippet: The last words of the famous tend often to be suspiciously witty, elegiac or pithy. This weekend, co-vocabularists are offered the chance to pre-record their final words, on the off-chance that they die bereft of a good one-liner, or without the b...
docs.lead_paragraph: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to suggest the final words they would like history to attribute to them.
docs.abstract: The last words of the famous tend often to be suspiciously witty, elegiac or pithy. This weekend, co-vocabularists are offered the chance to pre-record their final words, on the off-chance that they die bereft of a good one-liner, or without the benefit of a competent stenographer.

docs.snippet: Back when they were a couple, James Cameron and Kathryn Bigelow made a music video together featuring a gang of female gunslingers, for a band called Martini Ranch....
docs.lead_paragraph: A Bagger pal has pointed us to an incredible artifact of the early collaboration between Oscar frontrunners James Cameron and Kathryn Bigelow, back when they were Mr. and Mrs. It's a music video - the only one Mr. Cameron directed, apparently - for a shortlived band in the 1980s, Martini Ranch, formed by the actor Bill Paxton - who appeared in Ms. Bigelow's "Near Dark" - and the musician Andrew Todd Rosenthal. The group released only one album, "Holy Cow," but it had guest appearances from members of Devo (who had a little something to do with the track called "How Can the Labouring Man Find Time for Self-Culture?") and the B-52s, as well as Bud Cort ("Harold and Maude") and Judge Reinhold. Good god, the Internet is just fantastic.The video, for "Reach," includes cameos by Mr. Reinhold, Paul Reiser and actors from "Aliens" and "Terminator," and is, of course, set in the Wild West. Ms. Bigelow stars as the leader of an outlaw band of female gunslingers who manage to persuade a few good-time gals to join them. There's also a mariachi band that plays through a hanging and a guy buried up to his neck in sand, trying to get at a martini glass with his tongue. ("Reach!") It's over seven minutes long and the music doesn't start until nearly three minutes in, but that's for the best.
docs.abstract: Back when they were a couple, James Cameron and Kathryn Bigelow made a music video together featuring a gang of female gunslingers, for a band called Martini Ranch.

docs.snippet: The war movie can have four producers accept credit, after a decision that they "had fully functioned as genuine producers of the film."...
docs.lead_paragraph: The producers of "The Hurt Locker" and "The Blind Side" can start figuring out who they're going to elbow out of the way at the podium on Oscar night. Though it normally allows only three producers to accept credit for a film, the Academy has ruled that all four from "The Hurt Locker" - Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal, Nicolas Chartier and Greg Shapiro - "had fully functioned as genuine producers of the film," according to a statement, and bent its rules according to a clause which permits it to do so "under extraordinary circumstances." The decision follows an appeal by the "Hurt Locker" team. The three producers of "The Blind Side" -- Gil Netter, Andrew A. Kosove and Broderick Johnson - were also deemed acceptable, if one person short of extraordinary.
docs.abstract: The war movie can have four producers accept credit, after a decision that they "had fully functioned as genuine producers of the film."

headline.main: Academy Bends Its Rules for 'Hurt Locker'

docs.snippet: Behind the scenes at "Crazy Heart," a saga worthy of its own country song....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Oscar-sleeper "Crazy Heart," which this week earned three Oscar nominations -- one for Jeff Bridge's highly praised lead performance as a down-and-out country singer, one for Maggie Gyllenhaal's supporting performance as an admiring journalist and one for its music -- is also the source of a poignant, back-stage saga worthy of its own country song.
docs.abstract: Behind the scenes at "Crazy Heart," a saga worthy of its own country song.

headline.main: Behind the Scenes at 'Crazy Heart,' a Saga Worthy of Its Own Country Song
